results.headline: Creating Plays on the Go, Right Onstage
results.summary_short: Alex Karpovsky’s documentary films a New York show by the Chicago improv team T J and Dave, and preparations and post-mortems before and after a performance.
results.display_title: Trust Us, This Is All Made Up

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trust Us, This Is All Made Up

results.headline: Two Men and Not Quite a Baby
results.summary_short: “Patrik, Age 1.5” stares down prejudice with a nudge and a wink rather than a soapbox.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Patrik 1.5

results.headline: An Unusual Concert Tour
results.summary_short: León Gieco, the well-known Argentine folk singer, is determined to put the spotlight on others in the documentary “Mundo Alas” (“World Wings”).

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mundo Alas

results.headline: The View From the Lens of an Israeli Tank’s Scope
results.summary_short: The Israeli filmmaker Samuel Moaz wrote and directed this story of the 1982 invasion of Lebanon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lebanon

results.headline: Life, That Continuing Mystery, Should Be Lived, Not Worried Over
results.summary_short: Manoel de Oliveira raises questions about the nature of life in “Eccentricities of a Blond Hair Girl,” an adaptation of a short story by Eça de Queiros.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eccentricities of a Blonde-Haired Girl

results.headline: A Band of Neo-Nazis, Navigating Sexuality
results.summary_short: Danish men who harass Pakistani immigrants, beat up homosexuals and idolize Hitler while struggling with their own sexuality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brotherhood

results.headline: A Busy Love Life
results.summary_short: There are moments during the slog through “Lucky Days,” a dreary vanity project by Angelica Torn, that you think the whole thing could be a very, very deadpan parody.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lucky Days

results.headline: A Mountain View
results.summary_short: You may not believe it’s possible to bore people to death with a film about risking your life, but “The Wildest Dream” comes shockingly close.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wildest Dream

results.headline: A New Drug Is King in Manhattan
results.summary_short: “Twelve” is the latest book-to-screen titillation in a genre that wallows in the sophisticated travails of rich, potty-mouthed lost youth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Twelve

results.headline: Happy Feet Waging Hip-Hop Battles
results.summary_short: In “Step Up 3D,” the story of a dance crew moves to New York from Baltimore, the setting of the first two films in the series.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Step Up 3-D

results.headline: Revolving-Door Romances for Modern-Day Chinese
results.summary_short: “Spring Fever” portrays contemporary China as a seething hotbed of erotic curiosity and discontent.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spring Fever

results.headline: Imperfect Attendants
results.summary_short: Watching “The Parking Lot Movie,” a quirky documentary about, yes, a parking lot, is probably not unlike working at such a lot.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Parking Lot Movie

results.headline: A Not-So-Macho Cop’s Moment of Truth
results.summary_short: Will Ferrell teams with the director Adam McKay again, this time at a police station with Mark Wahlberg.

results.headline: A Purveyor of Prurience in a Family-Man Guise
results.summary_short: George Gallo’s “Middle Men” follows three men who are brokers in a booming global business: Internet pornography.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Middle Men

results.headline: A War Story Continued
results.summary_short: A good 75 percent or more of Ari Taub’s “Last Letters From Monte Rosa” consists of scenes and footage lifted directly from his film “The Fallen.”

results.headline: Creepiness and Twists in a Hostage Thriller
results.summary_short: A pair of kidnappers hold a woman hostage in this creepy, claustrophobic thriller, which is the feature debut of J Blakeson.

results.headline: Boxing Dreams
results.summary_short: In “The Kid: Chamaco,” the first feature from Miguel Necoechea, a Mexican boy dreams of becoming a famous boxer.

results.headline: A Man, a Woman and the Pyramids
results.summary_short: In Ruba Nadda’s “Cairo Time,” Patricia Clarkson and Alexander Siddig star as unexpected lovers exploring some of the wonders of Egypt.

results.headline: A Portrait of Depression
results.summary_short: In Sandra Nettelbeck’s drama, a wife and mother slowly loses her grip.

results.headline: From the Killing Fields, on a Mission of Truth
results.summary_short: Thet Sambath suggests a one-man Cambodian Truth and Reconciliation Commission. Instead of affixing blame, he seeks the healing power of confession.
